intro: Xyris organensis, commonly known as the Florida marsh yelloweye, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the genus Xyris, which is part of the family Xyridaceae, commonly known as the yellow-eyed grass family. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, including marshes and swampy areas, where it thrives in moist, sandy soils. Its flowers are yellow and bloom in late spring to early summer, producing small, clustered inflorescences. Xyris organensis is characterized by its grass-like foliage and its ability to tolerate periodic flooding, making it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
